trans-unit.source: Specifies access rights for specific key containers.
This class cannot be inherited.
This permission is intended to enable users to easily manage key containers when either a small number of keys is involved, or access is to be granted to only some keys.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry"></xref> class, using the specified cryptographic service provider (CSP) parameters and access permissions.
This constructor allows access rights to be assigned for specific key containers identified in a <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.CspParameters> object.
A <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.CspParameters"></xref> object that contains the cryptographic service provider (CSP) parameters.
A bitwise combination of the <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags"></xref> values.
The resulting entry would have unrestricted access.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry"></xref> class, using the specified key container name and access permissions.
This constructor allows you to specify access rights for specific key containers identified by name; use an asterisk ("*") to represent all the key containers.
The name of the key container.
A bitwise combination of the <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags"></xref> values.
The resulting entry would have unrestricted access.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry"></xref> class with the specified property values.
This constructor allows access rights to be assigned for specific key containers.
A `keySpec` or `providerType` value of –1 represents all key specifications or provider types.
A `keyStore`, `providerName`, or `keyContainerName` of "*" represents all key stores, providers, or key containers.
A `providerName` or `keyContainerName` that is `null` represents all providers or key containers.
The name of the key store.
The name of the provider.
The type code for the provider.
See the <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry.ProviderType*> property for values.
The name of the key container.
The key specification.
See the <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry.KeySpec*> property for values.
A bitwise combination of the <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags"></xref> values.
The resulting entry would have unrestricted access.
Determines whether the specified <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry"></xref> object is equal to the current instance.
The Equals method compares the properties of the two <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry> objects to determine if they are equal.
The <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry"></xref> object to compare with the currentinstance.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the specified <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry"></xref> is equal to the current <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry"></xref> object; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets or sets the key container permissions.
> [!CAUTION] > Many of these flags are powerful and permit access to key containers that should only be granted to highly trusted code.

The most powerful of the flags are <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags>, <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags>, <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags>, <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags>, <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags>, <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags>, and <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags>.
For specific threats posed by the use of these flags, see individual flag descriptions.
A bitwise combination of the <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags"></xref> values.
The default is <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags"></xref>.
Gets a hash code for the current instance that is suitable for use in hashing algorithms and data structures such as a hash table.
Serves as a hash function for the <xref:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry>, suitable for use in hashing algorithms and data structures such as a hash table.
A hash code for the current <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionAccessEntry"></xref> object.
Gets or sets the key container name.
Use a value of "*" to apply the access entry to all key containers within the specified provider name and provider type.
The name of the key container.
The resulting entry would have unrestricted access.
Gets or sets the key specification.
Valid values for this property are AT_KEYEXCHANGE (1) and AT_SIGNATURE (2).
The default value is –1, representing all possible values.
One of the AT_ values defined in the Wincrypt.h header file.
The resulting entry would have unrestricted access.
Gets or sets the name of the key store.
Valid values are "User", "Machine", or "*".
If `null` is specified, the value is set to "\*".
The name of the key store.
The resulting entry would have unrestricted access.
Gets or sets the provider name.
An example of a provider name is "Microsoft Enhanced Cryptographic Provider".
If `null` is specified, the enhanced cryptographic provider name is used.
The name of the provider.
The resulting entry would have unrestricted access.
Gets or sets the provider type.
One of the PROV_ values defined in the Wincrypt.h header file.
The resulting entry would have unrestricted access.
